facts.text: Smt. Vimla filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the court of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Vimla - hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff - filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara,

facts.text: Suit seeks decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites in sch. A, movables in sch. B, mesne profits for sch. A, possession management account for sch. C, institutions in sch. D as private family religious endowments

anchor.surface_text: for a decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites described in sch. A and movable properties described in sch. B and for mesne profits in respect of properties described in sch. A and for a decree for possession and management and for account of the properties described in sch. C and institutions alleged to be the private family religious endowments in sch. D.

facts.text: Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade died on August 31, 1955

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed that on the death of her father Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade on August 31, 1955, she became entitled to the properties in suit but the defendant wrongfully possessed himself of those properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff became entitled to the properties in suit upon father's death

anchor.surface_text: 1955, she became entitled to the properties in suit but the defendant wrongfully possessed himself of those properties. The plaintiff valued the properties in schs. C and D under s. 28 of the Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid a companyrt-fee of Rs. 275/-

facts.text: Defendant wrongfully possessed himself of the properties in suit

anchor.surface_text: the properties in suit but the defendant wrongfully possessed himself of those properties. The plaintiff valued the properties in schs. C and D under s. 28 of the Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid a companyrt-fee of Rs. 275/-

facts.text: Plaintiff valued properties in schs. C and D at Rs. 21,000/- under s. 28 of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 and paid court-fee of Rs. 275/-

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff valued the properties in schs. C and D under s. 28 of the Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid a companyrt-fee of Rs. 275/-. She valued the lands in schedule A for purposes of jurisdiction at 30 times the assessment and separately valued the buildings and paid companyrt-fee on that footing.

facts.text: Plaintiff valued lands in sch. A at 30 times the assessment for jurisdiction and separately valued buildings

anchor.surface_text: She valued the lands in schedule A for purposes of jurisdiction at 30 times the assessment and separately valued the buildings and paid companyrt-fee on that footing. On June 28, 1956, the Subordinate Judge ordered on an objection raised by his office that the amount of Rs. 34,577/- paid as companyrt-fee by the plaintiff was adequate.

facts.text: On June 28, 1956, Subordinate Judge held Rs. 34,577/- court-fee paid by plaintiff adequate on office objection

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1956, the Subordinate Judge ordered on an objection raised by his office that the amount of Rs. 34,577/- paid as companyrt-fee by the plaintiff was adequate. Then followed a companyrse of proceedings for which number many precedents may be found.

facts.text: Defendant filed written statement on September 9, 1950 raising objection to valuation of properties and court-fee

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1950, the defendant filed his written statement raising an objection inter alia to the valuation of the properties in suit and the companyrt-fee exigible on the claim.

facts.text: Trial court raised issue about adequacy of court-fee paid by plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt then raised an issue about the adequacy of the companyrt-fee, paid by the plaintiff. On February 13, 1957, the defendant applied for the appointment of a Commissioner to value the properties.

facts.text: On February 13, 1957, defendant applied for appointment of Commissioner to value properties

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1957, the defendant applied for the appointment of a Commissioner to value the properties. The companyrt dismissed the application and declared that the companyrt-fee paid was adequate.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed defendant's application for Commissioner and held court-fee adequate

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt dismissed the application and declared that the companyrt-fee paid was adequate. In Revision Petition 272 of 1957 preferred by the defendant to the High Court of Judicature at Bangalore,

facts.text: Defendant filed Revision Petition 272 of 1957 in High Court of Judicature at Bangalore

anchor.surface_text: In Revision Petition 272 of 1957 preferred by the defendant to the High Court of Judicature at Bangalore, the order passed by the Subordinate Judge was set aside and it was directed that the trial companyrt do ascertain the value of the properties for purposes of companyrt-fee in accordance with law after giving full opportunity to the parties

facts.text: High Court of Bangalore set aside Subordinate Judge's order and directed ascertainment of property value for court-fee, possibly by Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: the order passed by the Subordinate Judge was set aside and it was directed that the trial companyrt do ascertain the value of the properties for purposes of companyrt-fee in accordance with law after giving full opportunity to the parties and if need be by appointing a Commissioner to ascertain the present market value of the suit Schedule properties and decide the issue afresh on merits.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge appointed Commissioner who submitted report on valuation; defendant objected leading to further and supplemental reports

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this direction, a Commissioner was appointed by the Subordinate Judge. The Commissioner submitted his report as to valuation of the properties. Objections were raised by the defendant to that report and a further report was submitted by the Commissioner. On the direction of the Subordinate Judge, a supplemental report was submitted by the Commissioner.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held properties in sch. D were extra commercium and fixed court-fee exigible for possession claim thereon

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the parties, the Subordinate Judge held that the properties described in sch. D were extra companymercium and fixed companyrt-fee was exigible in respect of the claim for possession thereof, that properties described in sch. D were trust properties and s. 28 of the Madras companyrt-fees and Suits Valuation Act applied thereto as the dispute related to the right of management between persons claiming to be rival trustees,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held sch. D properties were trust properties and s. 28 applied as rival trustees dispute

anchor.surface_text: that properties described in sch. D were trust properties and s. 28 of the Madras companyrt-fees and Suits Valuation Act applied thereto as the dispute related to the right of management between persons claiming to be rival trustees, that the houses built on revenue paying lands had to be valued according to their market value and number at 30 times the land assessment

facts.text: Subordinate Judge valued lands in sch. A at Rs. 7,74,665/- and house-sites at Rs. 27,625/-

anchor.surface_text: and that the lands in sch. A were worth Rs. 7,74,665/- and the house-sites were worth Rs. 27,625/-. The plaintiff paid the additional companyrt-fee as directed by the companyrt.

facts.text: Plaintiff paid additional court-fee as directed by Subordinate Judge

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff paid the additional companyrt-fee as directed by the companyrt. Against the order passed by the Subordinate Judge, the plaintiff and the defendant applied by separate petitions in revision to the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: Plaintiff and defendant filed separate revision petitions to High Court of Mysore against Subordinate Judge's order

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Subordinate Judge, the plaintiff and the defendant applied by separate petitions in revision to the High Court of Mysore. The High Court heard the Advocate-General of the State and substantially companyfirmed the order passed by the Subordinate Judge except as to an institution described as Nelliyadi Beedu,

facts.text: High Court of Mysore confirmed Subordinate Judge's order except for Nelliyadi Beedu institution, directed trial court to determine if extra commercium

anchor.surface_text: The High Court heard the Advocate-General of the State and substantially companyfirmed the order passed by the Subordinate Judge except as to an institution described as Nelliyadi Beedu, in respect of which the High Court directed the trial companyrt to determine whether the institution was extra companymercium after giving an opportunity to both parties to put forth their companytentions and to lead evidence in that behalf.

facts.text: Defendant preferred appeal to Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136 against High Court order

anchor.surface_text: Against that order of the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the defendant with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Progress in suit frustrated for nearly five years due to court-fee disputes via revisions by defendant

anchor.surface_text: By recognising that the defendant was entitled to companytest the valuation of the properties in dispute as if it were a matter in issue between him and the plaintiff and by entertaining petitions preferred by the defendant to the High Court in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction against the order adjudging companyrt-fee payable on the plaint, all progress in the suit for the trial of the dispute on the merits has been effectively frustrated for nearly five years.

issues.text: Whether the defendant can make a grievance by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court-fee on his plaint

anchor.surface_text: We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court-fee on his plaint. Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. How ever by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.

issues.text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State

anchor.surface_text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. How by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is invocable against orders on adequacy of court-fee

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether by Act 14 of 1955 the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the defendant says that by Act 14 of 1955 enacted by the Madras Legislature which applied to the suit in question, the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision if an order contrary to his submission is passed by the Court. Reliance in support of that contention is placed upon sub-s. 2 of s. 12.

issues.text: Whether the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant, when no question of jurisdiction was involved

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant, when no question of jurisdiction was involved.

arguments.claim: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action

anchor.surface_text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.

arguments.claim: Recognising defendant's right to contest valuation and entertaining revisions has frustrated suit progress for nearly five years

anchor.surface_text: By recognising that the defendant was entitled to contest the valuation of the properties in dispute as if it were a matter in issue between him and the plaintiff and by entertaining petitions preferred by the defendant to the High Court in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction against the order adjudging court-fee payable on the plaint, all progress in the suit for the trial of the dispute on the merits has been effectively frustrated for nearly five years.

arguments.claim: Defendant has no grievance to invoke High Court revisional jurisdiction on adequacy of plaintiff's court-fee

anchor.surface_text: We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court-fee on his plaint.

arguments.claim: Adequacy of court-fee on plaint is primarily a question between plaintiff and State; defendant not aggrieved

anchor.surface_text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. However by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.

arguments.claim: High Court revision under s.115 CPC strictly conditioned by clauses (a) to (c); invocable only for jurisdictional error or material irregularity

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Defendant has no right to move superior court by appeal or revision against order on court-fee payable on plaint

anchor.surface_text: The defendant who may believe and even honestly that proper court-fee has not been paid by the plaintiff has still no right to move the superior court by appeal or in revision against the order adjudging payment of court-fee payable on the plaint.

arguments.claim: Madras Act 14 of 1955 s.12(2) invests defendant with right to contest adequacy of court-fee in trial court and to move High Court in revision

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the defendant says that by Act 14 of 1955 enacted by the Madras Legislature which applied to the suit in question, the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision if an order contrary to his submission is passed by the Court. Reliance in support of that contention is placed upon sub-s. 2 of s. 12.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate. Again, the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code

arguments.court_reasoning: Section only enables defendant to raise plea in trial court and assist court; no provision for revision to High Court

arguments.claim: s.12(2) Madras Act only enables defendant to raise contention on court-fee in trial court; no right to High Court revision

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section, in so far as it is material, provides Any defendant may, by his written statement filed before the first hearing of the suit or before evidence is recorded on the merits of the claim plead that the subject-matter of the suit has not been properly valued or that the fee paid is not sufficient. All questions arising on such pleas shall be heard and decided before evidence is recorded affecting such defendant, on the merits of the claim. ... But this section only enables the defendant to raise a contention as to the proper court-fee payable on a plaint and to assist the court in arriving at a just decision on that question.

arguments.claim: s.19 Madras Act provides for enquiry/commission on valuation but does not arm defendant with revision weapon

anchor.surface_text: The Act, it is true by s. 19, provides that for the purpose of deciding whether the subject-matter of the suit or other proceedings has been properly valued or whether the fee paid is sufficient, the court may hold such enquiry as it considers proper ... The anxiety of the Legislature to collect court-fee due from the litigant is manifest from the detailed provisions made in ch. III of the Act, but those provisions do not arm the defendant with a weapon of technicality to obstruct the progress of the suit by approaching the High Court in revision, against an order determining the court-fee payable.

arguments.claim: High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on court-fee at instance of defendant when no question of jurisdiction involved

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant, when no question of jurisdiction was involved.

holdings.text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.

anchor.surface_text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation emphasizing revenue collection over litigant obstruction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant lacks standing as matter is between plaintiff and state.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict textual limits on s.115 CPC; no application to mere valuation errors.

holdings.text: The defendant who may believe and even honestly that proper court-fee has not been paid by the plaintiff has still no right to move the superior court by appeal or in revision against the order adjudging payment of court-fee payable on the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section, in so far as it is material, provides Any defendant may, by his written statement filed before the first hearing of the suit or before evidence is recorded on the merits of the claimplead that the subject-matter of the suit has not been properly valued or that the fee paid is not sufficient. ... But this section only enables the defendant to raise a contention as to the proper court-fee payable on a plaint and to assist the court in arriving at a just decision on that question.

We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court-fee on his plaint.
